runs.text: Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this story is a folktale. Discuss other folktales students have read and ask students to predict what they think this folktale will be about.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
is a process or way of doing something.
do you use to tie your shoes?
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the phrase that tells where the family lives. (at the foot of a mountain)
What problem does the woman have? Find the sentences that answer the question.
What method do the characters use to get the turnip out of the ground? Explain.
Could this story happen in real life? Why or why not?
Have students reread the story during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this comic is about people reading different kinds of books to learn about something they want to know more about.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
is something or someone that gives help or information.
do you need if you are visiting a new place and do not know how to get there?
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word in the title that has the
What resource can the girl use to find a word in another language? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Why did the author most likely include the cat character in this text? Explain.
Have you ever used any of the books mentioned in this text? Where did you find them?
Have students reread the text during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Have students whisperread each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
Have students circle words with short /˘oo/.
Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have students read the sentence to a partner.

Discuss the different end punctuation for sentences 1 (period), 2 (question mark), and 3 (exclamation point). Model how you change your intonation when reading a question (raise voice at end) or exclamation (read with emotion). Then have students read the sentences consecutively.
Read the title. Explain that these are riddles. Each riddle contains clues about a noun. Students must identify the word.

For the first reading, read the first riddle and have students read the other riddles. Invite volunteers to solve each riddle. Then have students reread the riddles in pairs, alternating lines. Partners can switch lines during the rereadings.
Prompt students to find all words with /˘oo/
spellings in the riddles and circle them. Then have students chorally read the circled words. Ask students about the text to confirm understanding.
Say each word, guide students to write it, then proceed to the next word in the sentence.
Provide supports for words that are completely comprised of the phonics skills students have learned.
These supports include sound boxes, tapping the sounds, and so on.
Provide supports for the high-frequency words students have learned.
These supports include the Read/Build/Write routine.
When completed, have students read the entire sentence aloud.
Self-Correct: Write the sentences on the board, and have students self-correct. Take note of errors on each students Student Observation Form.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that students will read about dogsled racing in Alaska.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
her bird to hop on her shoulder.
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that names a driver in a dogsled race. (musher)
What happens when the mushers and dogs stop during the race? Find the sentences that answer this question.
How does the Iditarod honor working dogs? Explain.
How do you know that the sled dogs have been trained?
Have students reread the text during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Then ask them to chorally read it.
Have students circle words with short /˘oo/. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using
Have them read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss phrasing, or how to chunk longer sentences into meaningful parts.
For example, as you read sentence 3, pause briefly after
Point out that each group of words relates to one idea in the sentence.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to the word.
Explain that this text is about two kinds of dogsleds and what they are made of. It includes a diagram and labels.
Have students point to the labels that name the different parts of the dogsled.
Guide students through a reading of the selection, including the diagram.
Prompt students to share what they notice and wonder when viewing the diagram.

Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word. This is an on-level selection. It is provided to gauge where students are in their reading progress toward grade-level goals. Students might need to listen and follow along with the e-book for support before they read the book on their own.
Explain to students that they will read a folktale about a boy who kept lying.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
is to let someone know something.
drivers that emergency vehicles are nearby.
How does a computer or phone
Have students whisperread the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the phrase that tells what the boy does while the sheep eat. (read a book)
What does the boy say when the villagers run to help the boy? Find the sentences that answer the question.
The author says that the boy has learned a lesson. What lesson has he learned?
Why can it be dangerous to alert people to a problem that is not real? Explain.
Have students reread the story during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this story is a retelling of a folktale. Have students identify and describe the setting from the illustrations.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
to write a script for the class play.
When was the last time you had to
on a school project? What helped you work well with your partner or group?
Have students whisperread the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the phrase that tells what the traveler does after he fills a soup pot with water. (puts in a stone)
What does the girl add to the pot? Find the sentences that answer the question.
How does the traveler convince the townspeople to collaborate on making the soup? Explain.
What lesson did you learn from this story?
Have students reread the story during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
